147191337.review:
House Party is not your typical video game. It's more like a virtual frat party gone completely off the rails, and it's an absolute blast! This game takes you on a hilarious, unpredictable, and often outrageous journey that's not for the faint of heart.
The premise is simple: you're invited to a house party, and your goal is to interact with fellow partygoers and complete various quests. But here's the twist – the choices you make can lead to some wild and unexpected consequences. Whether it's trying to win over a crush, playing pranks, or getting embroiled in bizarre situations, House Party keeps you guessing and laughing all the way.

One of the standout features of this game is its interactive dialogue system. You can choose your responses, and these choices can lead to wildly different outcomes. The writing is sharp and filled with humor, making each conversation a delightful experience.
The characters you encounter at the party are eccentric, to say the least. From the suave ladies' man to the quirky and unpredictable guests, everyone has a unique personality that adds to the chaotic charm of the game. Building relationships with these characters, or antagonizing them, is all part of the fun.
While House Party may not be for everyone due to its mature content and irreverent humor, it's perfect for those looking for a raucous good time. Just be prepared for outrageous scenarios, cheeky humor, and the occasional awkward situation.

In the end, House Party is a game that doesn't take itself too seriously and encourages players to let loose and enjoy the mayhem. If you're in the mood for a wild virtual party that's equal parts absurd and entertaining, this game is definitely worth a try.

Yes, it's a sex game :)
In all honesty though, it's actually not that bad. There's a few solid characters here, all of which have strong feelings about this or that. There's tasks for you to do, and uh *ekhem* a [b] reward [/b]  system *ekhem* 

The Dev team has some solid sense of humour, cheesy for sure but a healthy amount in my opinion, all the way from the warning screen, in-game tips, some conversations, all the way up to some slightly 4th wall breaking remarks. There's also an "explicit content" DLC available for a little coin, you can also get it for free as a mod, however it's supposed to be considered as "last resort" in accordance to the description - the developers have acknowledged the existence of said mod and "formally objected to it's removal" which shows me that these guys are genuinely what I would consider "chill" and not money-hungry. It made me respect them a lot more, so I went ahead and bought the DLC out of my own pocket - they earned it in my mind and you should do the same if you can afford it :)
Furthermore, they're currently developing a new game, which allowed them to come up with new features, which they happily introduced into this game free of charge, which once again shows me their good faith, and makes me believe these guys are just out here to have fun rather than rip off their consumers out of their pocket money.

As for the story-line, uh, like for any porn - I play it for the plot, of course!
No, but seriously, it's not awful or cringe-worthy. You're at a party, every character has something going for them and you can help them out, crazy.
A cool feature here however, is that other characters will react to certain conversations if they so happen to be nearby, like - if you're trying to flirt your way in with one girl, and she overhears you do the same with someone else, she will get mad or even beat the shit out of you xd

Custom Stories made by other players are also supported and available, they change things up a bit and offer something new, which is always a big plus in my book.

House Party is Skyrim of adult games. It's been around, it's gone a long way since its first release... and it's got poor and frustrating game design.

To get chicks, you talk to them and do quests for them. This is fine at first, until you realize your wiggle room is as tight as a virgin. You picked a single suboptimal line in the dialogue and came a tiny bit short of a full "attraction" bar? Oh boy, hope you have a save from like 30 seconds ago. Savescumming wouldn't be that bad if it wasn't for the fact that even running a nvme saving/loading takes so long you can take a nap. This totally disrupts the game flow and makes it impossible to play without 5 open browser windows with walkthroughs. It would be great if there was a strategy guide of sorts provided in game like those adult VNs do this days, hell I'd even buy one as a DLC - but that unfortunately doesn't exist. As a result, you might as well get yourself an Excel spreadsheet for a gaming session. 

Don't get me wrong, the story and humor is fun, but you can't really get into it, because when you see an annoying guy you want to punch - you realize you can't do that, because he will no longer do a favor for you and that's gonna lock you out of two chicks, making you go back half an hour and replay the whole thing. The questlines also commonly branch out, locking you out of half the girls for a given playthrough. And while that normally would be good for replayability, here it just means you have to do everything leading to the branch AGAIN, which feels like a chore. 

In the end, while the chicks are fine and quest endings are often hillarious, there is so much padding here that by the time you get beyond it you feel too exhausted to enjoy the reward. Which is why I don't reccomend this.

If fine gentlemen from Eek! are reading this, I hope Office Party improves on this by:
- giving more leeway in getting desired outcomes with chicks and not locking them out unless you're really been a major dick to them;
- ensuring each of them gets at least a couple opportunities to hook up with, so that a single mistake didn't make you replay the whole thing, even if it means there won't be as many characters (less is more);
- optimizing the game for a comfortable saving time and/or providing a guide so that the player didn't have to dig through half of Google and Steam Guides section.

142098669.review:
First I'd like everyone who is possible reading this review to note that this game is, first and foremost, a puzzle game. Specifically a point-and-click type of one! BUT DO NOT LET THAT TURN YOU OFF FROM BUYING IT. 

House Party is one of the rare early access games that got continuous updates, actually listened to player feedback, and full released it's promised product. The best part is, the game still gets free events and the occasional update and the devs are very active on the Steam discussions page and such! That alone is worth a round of applause and plenty of praise, I think. 

Anyways, about the actual game: House Party is unique in that, despite all the lewdness and fun humor, it has deep point-and-click puzzle action going on. And not like, some baby easy stuff either! The house holds a ton of items that you can use and interact with in a lot of different ways to progress different stories. It's honestly surprising how many times you can restart the game and find something you've never noticed before in a simple two-story house. 

Besides the puzzle aspect, it's also a fun sandbox-y type game where you're free to basically do whatever you want. Grope people, piss on them, flash them, all of that good stuff! The several ways you can combine items and "prank" people (among other things!)

The dialogue/story is also surprisingly deep. Shmoozing a character and getting them to open up to you and their insecurities provides some actual good plot to an otherwise silly game. 

Here's a short list of pros and cons:

[b][u]Pros:[/u][/b]

- [b]Inclusivity![/b] For all my fellow gays, bi's, lesbians and everything inbetween, there is definitely stuff for you in here. Despite the male to female character ratio, the fact that you CAN romance the guys is a huge bonus. There is also a female character option and everyone is more than happy to get it on with you. Heck, even asexuals can enjoy the game for the story. No explicit DLC needed to enjoy this game at all. 

- Story

- Graphics

- Replayability

- Freedom to do what you want ingame

- Humor is on point and the dialogue consistently makes giggle

[b][u]Cons:[/u][/b]
- Probably the biggest one that quite a few people were/are upset about. The explicit content was originally part of the base game, but was separated and monetized. I personally didn't mind as I bought the game after the change happened, and I understand the devs separated it so people could play the game without getting banned on platforms and so the devs could release it on other storefronts. Even still, it still kinda sucks! 

- needs more bois at the party pls devs <33

--------------

All-in-all, It's absolutely worth the money. The devs showed they care about the game and its user base. For a small game, it's surprisingly complex and there's more getting added to it every so often. It does tend to get reptitive, but it is the perfect game that you can play around in for a few hours, forget about it for a couple months, then come back and play again. Can't wait to see how Office Party turns out!

139300198.review:
Paywall Predicament: House Party DLC Fails Players' Trust

House Party, a game that had the potential to offer an enjoyable social experience, has unfortunately taken a disappointing turn with its implementation of paid downloadable content (DLC). What was once a free DLC, accessible to all players, has now been unjustly hidden behind a paywall, leaving those who had already paid for it unable to access its content. This decision by the developer has shattered the trust of players and created an unfair and frustrating experience.

When I initially purchased House Party, I was delighted to learn that additional content was available for free to enhance the gameplay and enrich the party experience. It seemed like a generous gesture by the developer to reward players and extend the value of the game. However, to my dismay, the developer subsequently introduced a paywall, preventing players from accessing the very DLC they had already obtained or paid for.

This sudden shift in the availability of the DLC feels like a betrayal of the players' trust. It not only undermines the initial excitement surrounding the free content but also highlights the developer's disregard for the players' investment in the game. Players who had already obtained or purchased the DLC now find themselves unable to use it unless they pay an additional fee. This arbitrary paywall not only diminishes the overall value of the game but also creates a sense of unfairness and frustration.

Requiring players to pay a substantial amount for content they had already accessed or paid for is a slap in the face to the loyal player base. It raises questions about the developer's intentions and their commitment to prioritizing player satisfaction over monetary gains.

In conclusion, the paywall issue surrounding House Party's DLC is a severe blow to the trust and satisfaction of the player base. What was once a promising game with the inclusion of free additional content has devolved into an unfair and frustrating experience. The developer's decision to hide previously accessible DLC behind a paywall not only undermines the value of the game but also leaves players who had already obtained the content feeling cheated. It is disheartening to witness such a disregard for player trust and a prioritization of profits over player satisfaction.

139292354.review:
Overall, I want to give this game a "meh" or "it's ok". Overall, the base story line is enjoyable and has enough variety and replayability for multiple playthroughs. The 18+ content is good and for the most part the game itself is fun. Unfortunately, the base game is still buggy in certain situations nearly a year after release which makes you have to replay a whole bunch of the story unless you are regularly saving (autosave doesn't happen often enough for this to be viable). It also feels like the beginning of the story is the exact same each time around and the different paths don't really begin until mid-late story.

DLCs: I'm not going to make a fuss about the 18+ content being free before and now sitting behind a paywall as I didn't play the game prior to the paywall. I think the price is reasonable but I understand people not liking having to pay for something that was previously free for them.

The Halloween and Winter packs are ok. After a couple playthroughs I got annoyed with having them on and haven't turned them back on since.

The Doja Cat expansion pack is amusing but shouldn't be priced at a full DLC price since there is no 18+ content like all the other characters.

The Liz Katz DLC is well done and definitely the best out of the available DLCs. This was the most fun story to play through in my opinion.

139106690.review:
I'm really sorry I have to write a negative review for the game because I think it has a lot of very great ideas, and I would like to encourage more productions of that genre.

House Party is sold as a "party simulator" when actually it's the first-person equivalent of a point&click game: you explore freely, talk to people, find items, and combine and use them to discover more things to do. Basically, I love the idea.
Graphically, it may not be the most optimized 3D game, but for the budget, I think it's absolutely correct. I was even a bit impressed.

So what's the problem, you'll ask. Well, the problem is the same as many very old point&click: the solutions are completely obtuse. Do you remember the monkey wrench puzzle in Monkey Island 2? Well prepare yourself for a nostalgia trip into the worse parts of memory lane.
Did you enjoy having to start all over again from scratch when not doing exactly the requested chain of actions locked you out of half of the remaining game? Happy times indeed.
Or having to play a game from start to finish with the walkthough open on your lap? Well, nowadays, the walkthrough will just be opened in another window, but same idea.

Basically, I think it's too bad there was so many great ideas, and that all those ideas are spoiled because of very few completely outdated mechanics. It's so much more frustratng because I see it could have been a very great game.

Maybe I just didn't go into it with the correct state of mind...

136689143.review:
House Party is a good CYOA, comedy, sex game. The characters are realistic & they have depth, personalities & unique dialogue. Indeed, the characters sound authentic & their reactions are believable. Furthermore, all the female characters are attractive & sexy. Also, the writing is good, good enough that the game sometimes feels like a visual novel. There are a plethora of story paths to take. 

As well, the game world is small, consisting of the party house & its backyard. Despite this, the game world is dense & detailed, with lots to do & interact with & a lot of activity. In fact, one of House Party’s best features is that the characters react to you & almost everything you do. Moreover, you can interact with almost everything in the game world. It makes for a fun, very immersive experience & makes each playthrough unique.

As well, with so much content & so much activity going on, and with the ability to interact with almost everything, House Party has high replayability. It’s almost impossible to get bored with this game! For example, I have over 50 hours of playtime in the game. The Liz Katz DLC added several more hours of fun & I had a good time romancing the charismatic, sexy & hot Liz Katz! 

But unfortunately House Party has some major flaws. The game's biggest flaw is that the graphics are outdated or rather mediocre, especially the character models. This hurt immersion & made the NSFW content disappointing & mediocre, especially the sex scenes. Seeing a blocky female thigh clip into her body was a big sexual turn off. This was especially a problem with Liz Katz. And the low-quality animations only made matters worse. It's axiomatic that mediocre  NSFW content in an adult game like House Party is especially problematic.

Another major flaw of the game is that it lacks a gallery (unlike most adult visual novels). Hence, to see your favorite sex scenes, you have to create a ton of saves & it's a pain in the ass. Worse, every time the game updates, your saves no longer work. So in that case, you have to start over & redo everything, including your plethora of saves, just to be able to experience again your favorite scenes. It blows & I didn't bother. Hence, the sex scenes were a one & done experience, which royally sucks.

Finally, the sexual content is optional. If desired, you can bypass all the sexual content & simply play House Party as a comedy game. In fact, you have to buy an inexpensive DLC & enable adult content just to see the sexual stuff. So don’t let the label “adult game” scare you off. In sum, I recommend House Party. However, if you're looking for good NSFW content & a good story, adult visual novels are a much better option than House Party.

Each conversation is a bread crumb trail to potential sex relationships, but if you say the wrong thing you tick them off and sex may not be possible.  You also have to go around the house to locate items that you can use on other items or give to people to help progress the story.   

If you find enjoyment about puzzling out the right things to say for each individuals and finding all the items you need, you may enjoy this game.  Without a guide I expect it'll take multiple tries and lots of saves. While I usually play with the sound off, this game has sound and you may want to use during your sex scenes.  During sex scenes you may have some options, but teasing didn't appear one of them for me, which means you're going to end it quickly as opposed to any kind of simulation. The negatives for me is that this isn't really my play style, at least not with this game.   The graphics were pretty bad or dated.  There is a TON of clipping issues.  The being a jerk stuff, you can't really have fun with it due to realistic consequences.  Part of the fun of a video game is to be able to get away with doing things you might not normally do, at least when it seems like it's encouraging playfulness.   I was a little disappointed that the game was straight laced with all the females as opposed to being playful.   If you talk to people out of order, you also risk saying the wrong thing because your character is apparently an idiot without the right piece of knowledge and will insert their foot rapidly.  The camera scanning seems to lock up on occasion, and the game is sub-optimal on a touch pad.  A mouse would likely improve the experience for me, but that's not currently a real option for me.  The saving takes longer than I'd like with a few second pause.

If you want to quickly know if you'll like the game, I'd recommend one of the short stories that game comes with versus the main game.   Look up the control configs so you know how to navigate and then go play.   Even with a little trial and error they won't take long and you can decide if this is a purchase you want to continue with.  It's not a horrible game and I'm positive many will enjoy it more than I did.

So, the game will be for some people and it's not an adult novel which some may appreciate, but ultimately it's not for me. 129930348.review:
A lot of games advertise replayability as a sort of add-on, its a bullet point in the list of reasons why you should play their game and why you'll get great value out of it.

House Party forces you to replay it, over and over and over again, it's a core function. There are so many quest lines and pursuing one to completion often excludes several others. Not only that, pursuing one quest line forces you to begin and/or finish at least one or two others. I've always heard the term "branching story" thrown around by game devs but House Party really brings it to life. Thankfully, starting a new game doesn't feel like much of a hassle. If anything, you feel like you have a bit of a head start with each successive playthrough!

The characters are all interesting, everyone has a unique personality. Nobody in this game feels flat. The comedy is great and reminds me a little of American Pie. Every time I start a new game I always end up on a wildly different path than I was on before.

The main criticism of this game is that you have to take very specific actions in order to achieve a desired outcome, and they don't exactly make it easy to know what. There's some truth to that, at times I found the game really frustrating because it was basically like playing an obscure puzzle game. Then I'd go do another playthrough and hear ambient dialogue telling you exactly what to do. The devs did a great job of hiding things in plain sight. In many ways, the game rewards awareness of your surroundings, which is interesting because it's that exact awareness that helped me truly appreciate the game. It's not that these quest lines require things that are "too specific" it's that the devs want you to be clever in your decision making and if you fail on the first try, they want you to try again! Being pig headed is NOT going to get you anywhere here.

I'd also say that some of the rewards are grander than others, and it seems to be the bigger the reward is the more specific you'll need to play, the more experienced you'll need to be with the game's functions and the characters' quests.

There's also sex. Straight sex, gay sex, lesbian sex, threesomes, exhibition. Do not just expect some random porn sim though, the whole point of the game is that you're supposed to work for it. It's not really why I played the game but several people enjoy it in that respect.

I really appreciate the little disclaimer at the beginning, it brings up an interesting point. Why is gratuitous violence commonly accepted and why do we allow just anyone to watch it on Twitch? Why is it cringe to play a game like this but not some glorified war crimes simulator?

Idk, this game is awesome. I wanted a complex social sim and I got that and so, so much more. It's a gem, it's worth it even at full price.

The game follows the story of a young man/woman who has been invited to a house party by their friend. As the player, you must navigate the party and make choices that will determine the outcome of the evening. Certain actions you make can either help you out or completely sabotage you resulting in you having to reload, which adds to the challenge and excitement of the game. 
The dialogue and interactions between characters are well written and witty, making the game very entertaining, and it's great to be able to explore the house and interact with all the characters, each of whom have their own distinct personalities and stories. 
Overall, House Party is a great game that is sure to keep you entertained for hours on end. The story is engaging and the gameplay is fun and challenging. If you ever get the chance to play the wonders of House Party then I highly recommend you give it a go.

128025130.review:
A lot of games advertise replayability as a sort of add-on, its a bullet point in the list of reasons why you should play their game and why you'll get great value out of it.

House Party forces you to replay it, over and over and over again, it's a core function. There are so many quest lines and pursuing one to completion often excludes several others. Not only that, pursuing one quest line forces you to begin and/or finish at least one or two others. I've always heard the term "branching story" thrown around by game devs but House Party really brings it to life. Thankfully, starting a new game doesn't feel like much of a hassle. If anything, you feel like you have a bit of a head start with each successive playthrough!

The characters are all interesting, everyone has a unique personality. Nobody in this game feels flat. The comedy is great and reminds me a little of American Pie. Every time I start a new game I always end up on a wildly different path than I was on before.

The main criticism of this game is that you have to take very specific actions in order to achieve a desired outcome, and they don't exactly make it easy to know what. There's some truth to that, at times I found the game really frustrating because it was basically like playing an obscure puzzle game. Then I'd go do another playthrough and hear ambient dialogue telling you exactly what to do. The devs did a great job of hiding things in plain sight. In many ways, the game rewards awareness of your surroundings, which is interesting because it's that exact awareness that helped me truly appreciate the game. It's not that these quest lines require things that are "too specific" it's that the devs want you to be clever in your decision making and if you fail on the first try, they want you to try again! Being pig headed is NOT going to get you anywhere here. 

I'd also say that some of the rewards are grander than others, and it seems to be the bigger the reward is the more specific you'll need to play, the more experienced you'll need to be with the game's functions and the characters' quests.

There's also sex. Straight sex, gay sex, lesbian sex, threesomes, exhibition. Do not just expect some random porn sim though, the whole point of the game is that you're supposed to work for it. It's not really why I played the game but several people enjoy it in that respect.

I really appreciate the little disclaimer at the beginning, it brings up an interesting point. Why is gratuitous violence commonly accepted and why do we allow just anyone to watch it on Twitch? Why is it cringe to play a game like this but not some glorified war crimes simulator?

Idk, this game is awesome. I wanted a complex social sim and I got that and so, so much more. It's a gem, it's worth it even at full price.

126110863.review:
If you took Hitman and replaced 47 with some random dude trying to get laid, you'd end up with House Party. The game takes place in one sandbox level filled with unique NPCs that have their own personalities, backstories, relationships and quest lines. Quest lines offer branching paths and some quest lines are mutually exclusive, meaning you can't do everything (pun intended) in a single playthrough. The writing is generally funny and the characters and storylines are pretty memorable. As with Hitman, there's a lot of incentive to replay the game and explore every option just to see what happens.

Gameplay mostly consists of making dialogue choices and solving item-based puzzles. Most of the solutions are fairly intuitive, though there was the occasional puzzle that felt a bit contrived. There is optional combat too but it's pretty bad and best avoided.

My biggest complaint is that the AI isn't quite versatile enough to handle all the things you can do. For example, if you punch someone, then go hide in a bathroom and lock the door, the NPC will chase you and just continually run into the locked door. I'd expect them to recognize that the door is locked, wait a bit and then return to the party, only to attack me the next time they see me. Similarly, if I have a bottle of laxative, I'd expect to be able to mix it with any drink, give that drink to any NPC and then watch as they crap their pants because I locked all the bathroom doors.

Still, given its budget, I can't blame House Party for not providing the same reactivity as a Hitman game. Even with its limitations, I found House Party to be surprisingly entertaining. If you had told me I'd put over 30 hours into it, I'd have scoffed but here we are.

124816129.review:
Avoid this game.

The Bad:
1. Dear lord, why does this game take so long to load? I'm pretty sure N64 games needed fewer load times.

2. The animations are clunky, and the character models clip into each other too much during the lewd scene. The poor quality really unmotivated me to go after more lewd scenes.

3. Sometimes dialog to start a mission (called opportunities) just doesn't trigger. Or characters get stuck in a loop and you can't progress in an opportunity.

4. Some opportunities are tied into other ones, sometimes multiple others, and it's super easy to mess something up and get locked out of completing something.

5. Also sometimes opportunities just won't complete for no reason that is clear to me. It seems like I completed everything I needed to, but I'm not getting credit for it.

6. Because of all of the other issues with opportunities it makes it hard to figure out what I can and can't do to move forward with the game. I spend time running around trying to get something to trigger a new opportunity, and no one has anything new for me, and I can't do anything.

The Good:
1. Fully Voice acted, and for the most part, they all do a good job.

2. The character dialog is well written. Funny, and sounds actually sounds like something a real person would say.

Final Thoughts:
There are much better-looking games out there, and ones that work better as well. I would say if you're okay with reloading every 5 minutes because something didn't work right and can wait the 100 years for it to load each time, then give House Party a shot. It has some well-written dialog, and the open-ended and free-roaming gameplay is an interesting concept for this kind of game. I just don't think this team can execute it well

Is it good?
All I can say is, yes, there's sex in this game and full nudity if that's all you want, but to not talk about the character missions, diverse cast, clear love this passions project has received, different outcomes and constant hard work the devs put into this, not to mention the voice actors, both guest, which now also include the Grumps themselves, and the OG cast, would be vastly underselling how fun this game has been. 

Multiple play through sessions worth of content, choose your own adventure game with ridiculous caricatures who end up being more depraved than you could expect, but with a... slightly less vile core made of good intentions. Its tongue planted firmly in cheek helps keep the player character going (who is also a bit of a sleezy ball, but can have a slightly less gross core of like, about 7 carat to 16 carat gold. If I had to say anything negative, it'd be that there can be run ending bugs that stop mission progression all together and despite these being minor annoyances that can prevent you from completing a mission chain, 

House Party is a fun adventure game with lots of characters that get fleshed out through your own choices. Puzzles sometimes are nonsense and you can never escape that this house party is not much more than a means to get your player character laid, but having said that, this game is absolutely about the journey, not it's destination.Whether you want to admit it or not, Eek games managed to make a raunchy comedy adventure game that deserves the praise it gets. 123184319.review:
This is one of my favorite games but probably not for the reason you would think. It feels less like an "adult" game and more like a comedic intractable point and click adventure. You move around a house and have a variety of story lines you can pursue, all while collecting and finding things around the house in order to complete objectives. Each character feels unique and fun to talk to, and enjoying their interactions with others as they wander the house is hilarious. You can make enemies just as easy as you can make friends and it's a game where screwing up can cause some really funny moments that will make you rethink loading a save spot and trying again. Also you can just randomly pee on the floor because why not. 

The smut scenes are not really the focus of the game and for that they definitely feel a bit weird. The PC just kind of exists in a soulless scary way while the girls look into the camera with these glassed over dead eyes. They kind of play into the comedic tone of the game. I would not purchase this game if you're looking for a high level sexy experience. 

Overall huge recommend!! I do not recommend paying full retail price or purchasing any of the DLC which is very expensive in contrast to the games price, but it's a fun experience for sure.

What I am wondering, why the devs in game don't recommend switchting on the legacy POV scenes, in the end I prefer the cutscenes for variety sake, but these POV scenes are optional and also not bad in itself.

First off, the gameplay is a lot like a detective game where you walk around and find items to pick up and interact with. You use those items and selecting different dialogue options with NPC characters to progress the game, as well as sleep with almost any of the NPC players.

Even with the sexual content aside, the story line is hilarious. I love how items can be collected and combined. It has a lot of replayability to achieve certain outcomes. Playing as male or female characters have different actions and outcomes, so if you are an achievement collector, then *hint hint, wink wink*. 

There is such a wide variety of ways to interact with the characters and items. You can combine items in your inventory, combine inventory items with other items in the world, and give certain items only to specific characters and/or at specific moments (after following the right quest line or sequence of quest lines). *hint: Some items can be grabbed and moved but not put in your inventory and they still produce changes in quest lines or items to give to characters.

It is a puzzle to keep the NPCs happy or to make certain of them friends. Sometimes one character will like you more for something and it will cause another to like you less or to completely dislike you. This makes it challenging to sleep with everyone in the game or collect all of the achievements.

As far as the sexual content, I think the skin texture on the girls hands is pretty hideous but the rest of the base game is nicely animated. There is a filter for anything past being topless for m and f characters on the base game, unless you purchase the explicit patch. This game definitely delivers more than other games in this category with its style of realistic graphics, if I have yet to consider the explicit patch. I think its impressive how much body type variation there is between the female characters and they all look decent, including when topless. I wish there more archetypes of male characters.

I bought the explicit patch... I haven't really played it much yet but I am excited about having some extra interactions after playing the game a bunch of times.

119158595.review:
It's worth a play-through or two for the dialogue, but a lot is still pretty bad, even post-official-launch now.

Combat is a meme... it's the worst combat in any game I've ever played if I take it seriously as something meant to be a useful mechanic. Now, I *think* combat is supposed to be like the guns in the Battlefield series that do like 5 dmg, so, yeah, it's a meme. It would be okay-ish if just Frank obliterated you every time, but attack literally anyone and it's like you've ascended to lewd Dark Souls level difficulty.

The gamespace itself... it's literally a House Party, so, I can't get overly upset by that. But it's a cramped house... from Alpha until now, it's still, still, when I fired up briefly just a day or so ago, a pain to get around NPCs on the stairs or in the sliding door to the backyard.

I mean, it's mostly a fetch quest with a few very minimal elements of puzzle solving or crafting.

I applaud, however, the addition of Game Grumps (for free, no less), and the QoL type changes to some of the lewd stuff as well as some added other stuff (it has an intro, now, like a cinematic-style intro). And it's worth noting that this is one of the few lewd games with *both* full voice acting as well as a 3-D environment... most similar games on Steam are visual novels and/or do not feature voice acting. So, if you enjoy BaD or Acting Lessons, House-Party does has some advantages over those despite how limited it can feel. 

But while I give it a thumbs up, be aware that the only real draw is the irreverent tone and few good set-pieces of dialogue. Otherwise, it's a pretty small game-space to exist in with NPCs that don't really act that zany while idling in the background most of the time.

118588240.review:
So, bottom line up front:  There are better ways to see CG tiddies.

Pros:  
 - The Devs are actually pretty awesome and enthusiastic about their game and community.  Major props for that.
 - Constant updates and content additions.
 - The character models look good, if not fantastic; they appear to be models converted from Daz Studio assets. They serve their purpose.
 - The voice acting is better than you'd expect.
 - The sex scenes
 - The scenario editor allows users to create their own "adventures".

Cons:
 - The "humor" isn't that humorous.  It's juvenile at best but what can we expect from a porn game?
 - The updates often require starting the game from the beginning.  It gets old having to find pain meds for Patrick and obtain booze from Frank over and over.
 - Character animations can be a bit awkward and stiff.
 - The addition of internet personalities most people have never heard of; at least the people I know have never heard of them.
 - The scenario editor allows users to create their own stories BUT there are very few user made stories and most I've seen are just designed to get the characters engaged in sexual activities.

  So I decided to try House Party.  Yeah.  It's not that funny, at least in my humble opinion.  Sure I got a chuckle or two here and there but the humor here is on a juvenile high school level.  Let's be honest, though the game is supposed to be for people ages 18 and over, the real target consumers are socially awkward, under-aged boys.  The humor is appropriate to that age group I suppose.

  The game looks pretty good in the slightly dated way that Daz Studio's Genesis 3 characters do.  Don't get me wrong, the models serve their purpose and have physics applied to the most appropriate anatomical elements.  As the game has developed over time, the overall look has improved greatly.  The animations are a bit stiff and somewhat awkward at times and the occasional graphical glitch will rear it's ugly head.  Oddly, the glitches can tend to be funnier than the intentional humor.  I got a good laugh out of watching one of the female models run into difficulty navigating the stairs.  She suddenly started rag-dolling while impaled on the hand rail for the rest of that game session while continuing to carry on conversations as if everything was normal.

  The subject I want to discuss the most deals with the DLC content.  The devs began adding so-called celebrity guest characters to the game.  They're all internet celebrities so don't expect anyone from what would be considered "mainstream".  The first was Lety from Lety Does Stuff.  Who's Lety, you ask?  Exactly.  I'd never heard of her, but then people from my generation don't typically follow what the millennials do online.
  Then there are The Game Grumps.  Who are they?  Exactly again.  I'd never heard of them.  Supposedly they are a couple of really funny video game player/critics.  They're not funny.  At least, they're not funny in the game.  I don't know if they are in real life because, frankly, I haven't cared enough to look them up.  It's as if they were told, "Hey we wanna put you in the game, so send us some stuff you recorded and we'll build a scenario around it."  The Grumps tried to be funny, I suppose, but I personally didn't think so.  
  Finally we come to the third super special, secret, soon-to-be-revealed celebrity guest!  For a couple of months House Party players were teased about the identity of said guest and invited to guess who this sensational celebrity could possibly be based upon nothing more than a silhouetted image.  The weeks passed, the teasers kept coming and then the day arrived for the BIG REVEAL!  It's DOJA CAT!

F**K YEAH! DOJA CAT!   AWESOME!  

Wait, who's Doja Cat?  Exactly once more.  Yet another, I assume, celebrity from parts of the internet I have never visited.  Here I was hoping for, I don't know, Angelina Jolie or maybe some other personality.  That's what I get for letting my anticipation get the best of me.  I'm not knocking Doja Cat personally, I'm sure she's nice.

  I really don't know what else to say about the game.  The controls are responsive and I was happy about the inclusion of controller support.  I do like the fact you have to actually work for the sex scenes rather than having them served up in some contrived, unrealistic scenario like you'd get from Big Sausage Pizza porn.   

  The developers are highly enthusiastic about the game.  I'd sure like to see that level of enthusiasm in other studios.  The devs very much appreciate their audience and often integrate the recommendations of their players into the game.  They really put a lot of time and effort into the game and constantly push updates, bug fixes, and new content.  Which leads me to another point I want to make.

  Updates tend to alter the game enough that players are forced to restart the game from the beginning which gets stale really fast.  The majority of my almost 42 hours of play time consist of sporadic play sessions that end up with me starting over from the beginning.  The humor, as I've stated, does not weather very well through multiple viewings.

  Uh.  That's it I suppose.

  Overall, I have trouble recommending House Party.  It's not terrible.  It's not great either.  It's not overly expensive.  Still, there's not enough here to keep me engaged and there are other ways to see CG nudity out there if that's all you are playing House Party for.

This game saved my life.

I am 69.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

I bought this thinking it would be a fun college movie comedy type game, it isn't.
It's a classic point and click adventure in a 3D artstyle.
In just under 4 hours of play I think I let out 1 chuckle. the majority of my time was spent trying to discern how to get alcohol flowing in this "party".
There's guy, who seemingly nobody invited, who doesn't live there but is preventing people from drinking like they're kids in highschool.

Graphically the game looked quite nice but was riddled with screen tearing and character's both clipping and bumping into one another. Aside from that I found the music to be very annoying, having 1 track on loop for the entire time, even one of the characters comments on how bad the track is and how the girl throwing it can't seriously only have 1 song. So the creators decided to purposefully put this "joke" in there rather than just pay for some music - or even use some free use tracks.

On the subject of character's talking about things, I heard the same npc's say the same things over and over again, only for them not to come into play when addressing them. One continuously asks if anyone would help her play a prank on her sister. When you speak to her it's not in her dialogue. Strangely however I did get an option from her sister to play a prank on her.
Oh, and as for the characters, of the 12 or so that I met, I think 3-4 were ok and the rest were outright annoying.

Overall I found this game very boring, unfunny and monotonous. 3/10. If you like point and click adventures then you might get something from this.

113953161.review:
Bought this game in July 2017 to support this small team in Early Access. Played it for a few hours back then to test it out, had less content out at the time too but, figured I would get back to it when it was fully released. I liked that this game was pushing that line of normalising nudity in games. Personally have always found it an oxymoron how the industry is fine with murder, drugs & other adult rated themes yet, some nudity/sexual themes to be more taboo.

Now though they have removed content, the nudity/sexual parts of this game out of Early Access/The Game & are charging you separately for it. Content in Early Access is subject to change, it's part of the development cycle, I get that. What isn't normal though is for a developer to remove content out of a game, a big selling point of a game too, & later charge you separately for it. This game was sold as a game with sex & nudity. The devs even talk about it in the Early Access notes, a quote directly from the page; 

"This game is all about choice, and [b]hearing from our player base[/b] has better helped us understand which kinds of choices are [b]most important to the experience.  The answer usually had to do with more sex positions. [/b] You can’t say we didn’t listen.” 
Reading between the lines, seems they wanna charge now for the part, as they see it, & maybe the player base too "most important to the experience".

I had a patch they had on their website installed at the time, I believe later in 2018 they made it a free patch on Steam to install but having removed the game from my ssd to make space, never installed that separate DLC & now have to pay for it. I have emailed them about it too for a free code but, I got no reply back. *update they had old email listed by mistake on website but, still got back with a free code after checking there & getting back after a while*

[b]If you are ever going to grab this[/b], do it at a very high discount imo, bargain bin sale & there's no guarantee they don't repeatedly sell uncensored patch's either for any future dlc. or things like that but, how they move from here has yet to been seen.

I get the team is small & doesn't have Valve money but, there are ways to go about things with a more consumer friendly approach. I'm sure if they needed more money to fund the growing ambitions of the game, they could get it if transparent & consumer friendly about it.

- my 2 cents

[b]*Reply to Dev Reply*[/b]

Your project is in Early Access, no game is going to stay the same there, & will have things change. That's the whole point of a Early Access, it's not a Final Product. 113953161.developer_response:
It's more nuanced than that.  We have changed a lot of the content and the way it is delivered.  If you haven't played the game since 2017, it is drastically different now.  I would encourage you to take a look at the new DLC and what it actually offers vs the core product.  There are reasons we have to do it this way that are out of our control.  We are doing the best we can with what we have to work with.

Our goal is to deliver a better product to ALL of our customers.  Combine that with trying to grow as a company, and this is a tricky business!

That being said, you are grandfathered in.  Having bought this in 2017, you do not have to pay for the DLC.  When did you send us the email?  We are not in the habit of ignoring any communications to us, Discord or not.  We are a small team dealing with a a lot of customers, so we do the best we can, but I would imagine if you didn't get a response, something went wrong that we are unaware of and we may not have gotten your inquiry.  We have given out plenty of keys and will continue to honor any purchases before March of 2022.

We are more in tune with our customers than you make this review out to be.  It's just that different people want different things.  Some people are not interested in the explicit content and want us to grow in other ways, and some customers only want us to do more explicit content.  We are trying to find a happy medium that allows us to give choice to all of our customers that falls in line with not being held back from growing as a company with the restrictions that are placed on content creators like us.  Our primary goal though, has and always will be, making a fun engaging kick-ass game and pushing the envelope as you mention above.  We are listening to all of our player's feedback and doing our best, always.

111841969.review:
I know it's something about the dialogue and the way the faces are animated, but this game gives me a frequent and strange sensation similar to when I played Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodline. I couldn't give you any one specific example but this games comes off as something by Stephen king or Lovecraft or Something Else Entirely. But... my brain is weird and works weird... I wouldn't think too hard about it.

Mooooving on

House Party comes off as a simple idea, you're a person, and here is a party. Horror game vibes, am I right, fellow anxiety people? Very quickly the party mingling gave me a plethora of fairly straightforward ideas to work on to improve your standing amidst the strangers. The people you meet are fairly distinct and provide well written dialogue. A few hours in, I have lived this groundhog day many... many times. Always reaching for the torch of sweet burning victory, I am met by Frank who through one reason or another has caught my shenanigans and sentenced me with an induced coma. Sometimes I attempt to be stealthy in my maneuvers only to be met by his skilled protegee Leah who proceeds to stun lock me harder than a hammer does to repeated headshots on a Rathalos. 

Planning is needed, timing and cunning my tools. What are my goals? Do I even have goals? Does time and space collapse around this house forever condemning me for my sins? 

Oh hey, a skeleton key to the bathrooms AND a beer? :) 

Now I sacrifice precious beers to buy trust, strike up friendships, alliances, conspiracies, and a thermos containing destiny itself. 

Am I playing as an infant god playing around in a micro universe of it's own creation? Learning to dodge and weave in the tactical withdrawal and placement of items, whispering twisted truths to set others off to pursue my goals under the guise of free will, turning the party goers against themselves so I can grab a victory I cannot even visualize. Who was I coming into this party? The stories Derek told echo of a familiar but distant memory to what I have become in these repeating lives in an infinite night. What will I be at the end of this? What is the grand line of events to arrange and set in motion? What domino effect will unfold as the manifestation of my will? Or... am i just a puppet to it's will? Will I finally stop misclicking in the dialogue with Derek and wind up with him trying  to beat me up? I don't know.... but I intend to find out. 

10/10 Fantastic party simulator that is probably(?) not a secret horror game. Also with adult elements if you want them, nothing negative to say about the craftspersonship regarding that at least. 

Buy it, enjoy it, question what lies beyond the night sky because of it. House Party.

107650802.review:
This game saved my life.

I am 45.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiralling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

106753307.review:
[u][b]What is House Party:[/b][/u] A house party simulator with all the fixins.

[u][b]Summary:[/b][/u] [i] The premise is simple: You are a new guy at a college party filled with all sorts of colorful characters. What will you do? Who will you talk to? What is there to see? Can you get laid? Will you cause problems? Get drunk maybe? Piss on stuff? Introduce yourself to people with your dick out? It's really up to you. The premise allows for an abundance of playthroughs each with different outcomes based on your actions, and the gameplay backs that up. There really is a lot to unpack here, so let me start with the gameplay basics.

Played from the first person perspective, you walk around the house, using the left click to interact with things and people, prompting a radial menu allowing you interact in various ways. You can talk to people, inspect people or items, pick stuff up and carry it around or put in your inventory. You can press various buttons, which you will be tutorialized on, to bring up various contextual menus. "Y" for example brings up a personal radial menu that lets you strip articles of clothing or start dancing. You can even pull your dick out, piss on stuff, or jerk off on stuff. It's a hell of a lot of fun just to walk around the house jerking off on people. That will more than likely ruin most opportunities you may have had with said people, prompting for a restart. But it's definitely worth it to have that one good crazed jerk-off guy playthrough. 

Talking to people will prompt you with various dialogue options, all of which can be altered or expanded on based on your actions, the situation, items you have given, or a plethora of other factors. The party is filled with an assortment of college tropes. There is the straight edge jock guy, the party animal, the slutty chick paying her way through college by stripping, and many more across a selection of like (15?) characters to interact with. I can't stress enough that your choices matter. Each person has a set of stats that show your relationship with them, and their current mental state. The things you say or do will absolutely have an affect on certain opportunities in the game, either advancing them, revealing them, or causing you to fail them. 104856269.review:
If you're already into this type of game (open-ended/multiple endings, adult themed, mission-based), then I think you'll probably enjoy House Party, and for you, I'd say:  don't even hesitate, get this game.

If you're not into these kinds of games, then probably don't bother with this one.

A few caveats:
- This game is Early Access and feels like it.  It has a few bugs here and there, it might glitch out on you and crash in unexpected/unpredictable ways.
- Some of the missions have oddly specific progressions that can be frustrating.  One example of this:  There's a mission where you have to open a locked door, and there's an option to "Unlock" the door, and a separate option to "Open" the door.  If you "Unlock" and then "Open", nothing will happen.  But if you simply "Open" the locked door (for which you have a key), then the door will open, and the mission will continue.  Funky things like that are minor, but still annoyances
- Some of the pathfinding looks kind of awkward and clunky.  E.g., watching NPCs navigate their way through an open door, or around obstacles/other NPCs, can look funny... But it generally works. And pathfinding is hard - even in 2D.  This game is 3D and the paths can go up/down stairs.  Overall, the devs have done a commendable job here.

But on the flipside:
- The dev/discord community is active, and it feels like the game is definitely being maintained.
- There is no shortage of walkthroughs/forums/wikia documentation to guide you through.
- The jokes in this game are funny; the adult scenes are well-done.  Animations, interactions, etc.. All of it's pretty solid (Aside from the stuff I mentioned above)

Don't try to figure this game out by yourself! Use the Force!  Er, I mean, the community!

One other note:  Apparently the Steam version, even though it's uncensored for most NPCs, was patched to censor NPCs that are based on people in real life.  That seems to piss some people off; I bought this game after that patch was implemented, so it doesn't bother me all that much.  But if that bothers you, then consider getting this game on itch.io or GameJolt.
